comments.raw_text:
To get a repository account I obtained an S/MIME certificate and tried to sign my e-mail. I helpfully got prompted with the following:

"You need to set up one or more personal certificates before you can use this security feature. Would you like to do so now?"

So I did, and selected the certificate for "Digital Signing", got prompted if I also wanted to use it for Encryption, answered yes, and then I checked to make sure my message was actually signed.

It wasn't. So I tried to sign it again and got the first prompt which took me to account preferences, where of course the certificate was selected for both.

It took me a while (embarrassingly long[0]) to realize that I was sending from a separate identity (jag-mozilla@ instead of jag@) and that I needed to set the certificate for that identity instead of my main one.

So, can we make it so that for additional identities we go to their security panel instead?

[0] In my defense, Thunderbird's helpfulness was working against me.

comments.raw_text: You need to set it per identity, yes. are you asking for an auto match between certs and email addresses ?
comments.author: ludovic@hirlimann.net
comments.creator: ludovic@hirlimann.net
comments.text: You need to set it per identity, yes. are you asking for an auto match between certs and email addresses ?

No, though an auto-match (or auto pre-fill, e.g. when you import the certificate) would be nice too, but that's a different issue.

The issue here is that when you try to sign, the helper (wizard?) takes you to your account's main Security pref panel, not to the Security pref panel for the identity you're currently using. It's steering you in the wrong direction, and left (at least) me very confused why things weren't working even after I did what I was asked to do.

Yes, I probably should've realized a bit sooner that certificates are per identity, not per account, and I probably would've thought about it if there hadn't been the helper steering me to what seemed to be the right place.

This is probably not a very high priority issue, I suspect identity usage is low, but the helper/wizard's behavior is less than helpful.
